column2: colloquially known as "Cat City"
column3: is a desert resort city in Riverside County
column4: California
column6: within the Colorado Desert's Coachella Valley. Situated between Palm Springs and Rancho Mirage
column7: the city has the second largest population
column9: of the nine cities in the Coachella Valley.  Its population was 51

column1: Prior to the arrival of European explorers and settlers
column2: the land was part of the territory inhabited by the Cahuilla Indians. Today every other square mile of the city is part of the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians reservation land. Development of a town began when a housing subdivision was built in 1925
column3: although it was not incorporated until 1981.

column1: The city's name is derived from Cathedral Canyon located to the south of the city in the foothills of the Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument. The canyon is said to have received its name because certain rock formations in the canyon were reminiscent of a cathedral. A flood in August 1946 significantly altered the cathedral-like features of the canyon. In the United Kingdom a Cathedral city is a town that has achieved "city" status and is typically the location of a cathedral. This prompted Robert Ripley to include the town of Cathedral City in his December 9
column3: Believe It Or Not column stating
column4: "Believe it or not … there is no church in Cathedral City
column5: Calif. It is named after a canyon".

column1: Cathedral City sits at the northwestern end of the Coachella Valley between the San Bernardino Mountains to the north
column2: and the San Jacinto Mountains to the south
column3: with the San Gorgonio Pass to the West.  The earliest established inhabitants of this region were the Cahuilla Indians.  They arrived in the area around 3
column4: 000 BCE.  The Cahuilla were organized into bands of about 600 to 800 people
column5: and it was the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians who inhabited the lands that included what would become Cathedral City
column6: California.The land was claimed by Spain in 1768 when Spain established Las Californias
column7: a province of the Viceroyalty of New Spain
column8: and then by Mexico in 1821 when Mexico and Spain signed the Treaty of Cordoba. At that time the province had already been renamed and expanded into the larger Alta California province.  After the Mexican-American War
column9: and with the signing of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo in 1848
column10: possession of the land was formally transferred to the United States
column11: and it officially became part of the State of California when the state was formed in 1850.

column1: In 1852 US Army Colonel Henry Washington
column2: a nephew of George Washington
column3: the first President of the United States
column4: was contracted by the government to survey Southern California.  On November 7 of that year he established the initial point
column6: from which all future surveys in Southern California would be based.  In 1855 he was contracted to continue his work and survey the Coachella Valley.  It was then that he found and named Cathedral Canyon for which Cathedral City would be named.Besides Colonel Henry Washington
column8: colonizers and soldiers that made their way through the area during the Spanish
column11: but none established any permanent structures or residences.  The Cahuilla remained the only people known to be living in the area.

column1: Prior to the 1860s the only regularly traveled routes through the Coachella Valley were trading paths used by the Cahuilla and other Native American tribes.  One of these paths
column2: on the southwestern side of the valley
column3: followed the base of the San Jacinto and Santa Rosa mountains somewhere near the Whitewater River
column4: and would have passed through the area that would become Cathedral City.  Early non-native explorers
column9: but regular transportation services were not established until 1862.

column2: which started in the spring of 1862
column3: prompted William D. Bradshaw
column4: a frontiersman
column5: to seek a quicker route from Los Angeles to the Colorado River.  Later that year he hired a guide
column6: and with the help of the Cahuilla and Maricopa Indians
column7: mapped a route from San Bernardino
column9: through the San Gorgonio Pass and Coachella Valley
column10: past the northern shore of the Salton Sink
column11: through the passes between the Chuckwalla and Chocolate Mountains
column12: and up to the Colorado River across from La Paz in the New Mexico Territory
column13: (now the state of Arizona).  Much of the route is thought to have followed the original southwestern trading path used by the Cahuilla.

column1: Shortly after Bradshaw defined the trail from San Bernardino to La Paz
column2: various stagecoach and freight companies began using the route.  The stage and freight lines brought miners
column3: supplies
column4: and mail between San Bernardino and La Paz
column5: and the route became known as the Bradshaw Trail or “Gold Road”.  The Bradshaw trail
column7: passed through the future Cathedral City
column8: but the nearest scheduled stops were Agua Caliente (now Palms Springs)
column9: and Indian Wells (now Indio). The stage and freight lines were eventually supplanted by the railroads
column10: but the trail would later become the basis for Palm Canyon Drive and Highway 111 that run through the city today.

column1: Cathedral City has an automotive mega-dealership known as the Palm Springs Auto Mall based on the city limits with Palm Springs.
Cathedral City hosts an annual Mexican Independence Day festival on every third weekend of September. To commemorate the event
column2: an "el Grito de Dolores" is held at the city hall/movie theater complex.
